Title: the staircase implementation

Penny: Okay, Babydoll Pink, let’s see if you can cover up the fact that I got my dad’s feet.
Hang on.
Uh, well, you can try, but the people across the hall are being very noisy.
Apparently, the one fella tried to adjust the thermostat, then the other fella went bat-crap crazy.
Well, not as nuts as the guy who chooses to live with him.
Oh, I do not believe that.
So Sheldon’s last roommate tried to warn you off?
Well, yeah, he’d been living with Sheldon.
Okay, and after all that, you just moved in?
Why on earth did you agree to all that?
Well, I’m sorry, Leonard, it’s very hard to feel sympathy for you.
Oh, my God.

A little bit. Okay. Let me get this straight. You move in with this guy, he makes you sign a ridiculous roommate agreement, then he walks into your bedroom while you’re doing this Joyce Kim, and you still stay?
Why not?
What does that have to do with Joyce Kim?
So, what, that’s it? You’ve stayed with Sheldon all this time because he kept you from going to federal prison?
Oh, yeah, I’m wondering about that. You said it was working when you moved in.
Okay, what does all this have to do with the elevator?
Okay, how do you know he said that? You left the room.
Fine. Go ahead. (Flashback to Howard’s bedroom.)
So, why was it his lucky day?
What were you doing with rocket fuel in your apartment?
Are we ever going to get to the elevator?
Okay, so, basically, you’re the reason I have to walk up and down three flights of stairs every day?

Excuse me, I was in high school. Studying, keeping my nose clean, doing volunteer work for the community. (Flashback. Penny is in her bedroom, sitting on the bed with a guy, looking at a pregnancy tester.)
Leonard (voice off): It’s just two degrees, Sheldon. I just want to turn up the thermostat two degrees!
Yes, if we lived in a teakettle.
You know what, go to Hell and set their thermostat.
Oh, so the dialogue offends you?
Sheldon: (voice off): Let me point out that two degrees can be the difference between water and steam.
This is the temperature you agreed to in the roommate agreement.
No, you don’t screw the roommate agreement. The roommate agreement screws you.
I don’t have to go to Hell. At 73 degrees, I’m there already!
Leonard: Leonard.
Can I sleep on your couch tonight?
You heard that, huh?
So you agree, he’s nuts.
Believe it or not, he was worse when I met him.
That should have been my first clue.
For all I knew, he was the crazy one. He had this really deranged look.
Sure, it makes sense now. (Flashback. Past Leonard is getting out of the lift). Anyway, I went upstairs and knocked on the door.
In retrospect, that was clue number two.
It was the best apartment I’d seen, the rent was very reasonable and after you’ve passed the first three barriers you kind of want to take it all the way.
Okay, how about this? Let me tell you about the first time I brought a girl over. (Flashback to Leonard’s bedroom.)
Do I get some sympathy now?
Actually, I couldn’t get too mad at him about Joyce Kim.
Well, I was doing some government research at the time, you know, military, rocket fuel. It’s kind of secret.
As it turns out, she was a North Korean spy. Luckily, Sheldon drove her out before I revealed anything important. Which I’m not saying I would have.
That was part of it. The other part is what happened with the elevator.
It was, but one night, Sheldon came home from work… (Flashback, the apartment. The settee has now appeared. Leonard, Howard and Raj are playing a video game.)
I’m getting to it. (Back to flashback.)
Hey, do you want me to finish working on your man feet or not?
Well, it turns out I had a little rocket fuel in the apartment.
Mm, Joyce Kim was kind of curious about what I did for a living, and I was going to kind of show it to her. It’s not important. The point is, the guys and I went back to the apartment.
Yeah, we’re really close. Uh, uh, we’re at the apartment. (Flashback.)
Not only did Sheldon save my life, he didn’t rat me out to the landlord. Or the police. Or Homeland Security.
So I did something stupid. I’m sure you did stupid things when you were younger. What were you doing seven years ago?
Hey.
Oh, uh, clear nail polish. I had a mani-pedi. Men can get those. Anyway, I may owe you an apology.
I did agree to the thermostat setting, and I shouldn’t have tried to change it.
Okay, I’m sorry.
So, we’re good?
Never mind. Okay if I watch some TV?
Leonard: You are so naive. Just like I w: The lobby) I’d just started at the university.
Past Leonard: Excuse me, I’m looking for Sheldon Cooper’s apartment.
I’m Leonard Hofstadter. I called you about the apartment. You said…
Oh, uh, well, that’s tricky. Um, well, uh, Original Series over Next Generation, but Picard over Kirk.
I don’t understand, their, their existence is conditional?
Okay, I suppose I could drive you. Well that’s a point in my favour, right?
Uh, I’m gonna go with preserving the knowledge.
Oh, good. I passed the barriers.
I, I’m sorry, uh, in the morning. Around eight.
If people don’t go in there, and you’re people, and… You are people, aren’t you? Making a joke.
Does that really need to be in the agreement?
Shh. Just pretend we’re not here.
What do you want? I didn’t say come in!
I didn’t even know her 12 hours ago.
Hey, Sheldon. This is Howard and Raj. They work at the university, too.
Oh, well, there were some people on the first floor moving out, and they sold it to me for a hundred dollars. Howard and Raj helped me bring it up.
They’re lawn chairs. And there was no place for company.
According to the roommate agreement, I’m entitled to allocate 50% of the cubic footage of the common areas.
What am I doing in your spam folder?
There you go– three against one.
But I said no to that.
We can fix that. Let’s leave.
Oh, man. Is that a two-stage rocket?
Oh, this just might be your lucky day.
The trick is to mix it into Tovex in order to create a combustible gel that will generate over 8,000 kilonewtons of thrust.
Excuse me, but I’ve been working on this a long time. Trust me, it’ll work.

Okay, I’ve had it with you. You might be an expert on theoretical physics and science-fiction programs and where to sit on a freaking couch, but this is applied physics. And when it comes to applied physic… uh-oh.
A bad thing. A very bad thing. Get the door. Get the door! Get the door! Get the door! Get the door!
What’d you do that for? I had plenty of time. (Elevator explodes.)
Man with a box: Oh, I bet you’re here to check out the room for rent.
Man: Run fast, run far. (End of flashback.)
Transvestite: No, you want the crazy guy across the hall.
Past Sheldon: Yes?
I know what I said. I know what you said. I know what my mother said on March 5, 1992. What is the sixth noble gas?
You said you’re a scientist. What is the sixth noble gas?
Are you asking me or telling me?
All right, next question. Kirk or Picard?
Correct. You’ve passed the first barrier to roommate-hood. You may enter.
That depends.
No, but your ability to perceive their existence is conditional on you passing the second and third barriers.
Each more daunting than the last. Have a seat.
No! That’s where I sit!

This seat is ideally located both in relation to the heat source in the winter and a cross breeze in the summer. It also faces the television at a direct angle allowing me to immerse myself in entertainment or game play without being subjected to conversation. As a result, I’ve placed it in a state of eternal dibs.
Cathedra mea, regulae meae. That’s Latin for my chair, my rules. Now, you said on the phone that your area of study is physics.
Hmm.
Doesn’t concern you. You’ll be going to the university every day?
And you have a vehicle?
And you’ll be willing to drive me?
I can. I choose not to.
Why don’t you let me do this.

Last question. In a post-apocalyptic world, which task would you assign the highest priority? Locating a sustainable food source, re-establishing a functioning government, procreating, or preserving the knowledge of mankind?
That’s correct. FYI, I would have accepted any answer other than procreating. Come, I’ll show you the rest of the apartment.
The second barrier. Don’t get cocky. This is the bathroom. Are you fairly regular?
This isn’t going to work if you’re guessing. When do you evacuate your bowels?
When you have to? I’m sorry, I don’t rent to hippies.
I can’t give you eight. I can give you seven thirty.
Third barrier passed. You have won the right to see your room. Huzzah!
No, this is my room. People don’t go in my room.
I don’t understand.
Do you do this often?
Your room. You may want to repaint. (End of Flashback)
Roommates agree that Friday nights shall be reserved for watching Joss Whedon’s brilliant new series Firefly.

We might as well settle it now, it’s going to be on for years. Initial here. All right, that’s television and movies. Section nine, miscellany. The apartment’s flag is a gold lion rampant on a field of azure.
Never fly it upside down unless the apartment’s in distress. And next, if either of us ever invents time travel, we agree our first stop will be this meeting today in precisely five seconds.
Well that’s disappointing. (End of flashback.)
(Knock, knock, knock) Leonard?
(Knock, knock, knock) Leonard?Leonard?
I’m just going to keep knocking till you answer. (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard? (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard? (Knock, knock, knock) Leonard?

You asked what I wanted. I wanted to come in. I’m here because you violated our roommate agreement. Specifically, section eight, visitors, subsection C, females, paragraph four, coitus. Roommates shall give each other 12 hours notice of impending coitus.”
12 hours? (End of flashback.)
What is going on here?
I’ll get to you later. What are you sitting on?
Explain the couch.
But what’s wrong with the furniture we have?
Did it occur to you that was by design?
But you didn’t notify me by e-mail, so this is still a breach.
Oh, you did, did you? Oh, drat! Hoisted by my own spam filter.
I put you there after you forwarded me a picture of a cat playing the piano, entitled this is funny.
I assure you, you’ll be sorry you wasted your money on an iPod when Microsoft comes out with theirs.
Yes.
It’s not an assumption. Change seats with me.
I don’t like this spot. I have to keep turning my head.
We don’t watch Babylon 5 in this apartment.
Because no one likes Babylon 5.
They don’t get a vote. It’s one against one. And according to the roommate agreement, all ties will be settled by me.
And I said yes. And I settle all ties. Change seats with me.
There’s a draft on my neck over here.
You’re protected by your turtleneck.
Hmm, I’m still not comfortable. Of course. There’s too many people here.
Wait. Let me get my jacket.
Why not?

Oh. Well, in that case, I don’t need my jacket. And for the record, the correct syntax is I’m the guy from whom you’re trying to get away. Oh, yes, this is definitely going to be my spot. (End of flashback.)
Won’t work.
You don’t see your mistake, do you?
This is for a full-scale rocket, not a model.
Not correctly.
Give me that. (Takes the rocket fuel. Puts it in elevator. Presses button and jumps out.)
You’re welcome. (End of flashback.)

Yeah, we can go over to my place.
I don’t have playdates! I have colleagues!
No, but if you keep screaming, maybe they’ll hear you!
She grows any more hair on her face, yes.
Three. I designed the engine myself.
Oh, probably, if I could get my hands on that new fuel the government’s been working on.
I haven’t seen your Oreos! Just take your bath without them! (End of flashback.)
Past Raj: Oh, yeah, I saw that. That was hilarious. (End of flashback.)
